text.p: Shares of one of Chile's largest supermarket chains, Supermercados Unimarc Inc, were priced at $16.75 each after the market close on Thursday, the eve of its market debut on the New York Stock Exchange.
According to lead underwriter Salomon Brothers, the shares were priced within their estimated pricing range of $16 to $18 each.
The company will offer 4.46 million American Depositary Receipts (ADRs) on the NYSE under the symbol "UNR" Friday. It will also sell shares on the Santiago market.

The company hopes to raise about $70 million from the offering, which will be used to double its number of stores. Unimarc is owned by the investment group Inverraz. Unimarc hopes to raise around $70 million from the placement to finance plans to double its number of stores in coming years.

Unimarc is the second Chilean supermarket chain to trade on the NYSE. Shares of Santa Isabel SA were launched on Wall Street nearly two years ago and another, D&S SA, plans to issues ADRs later this year or in early 1998.
Unimarc represents the 20th Chilean firm to start trading in New York.
